Recently I‚Äôve been very unhappy with Firefox and Chrome. As a ‚Äúpower user‚Äù I think they‚Äôre really limited and extensions like Vimium can‚Äôt really be that polished. I‚Äôve used Qutebrowser before but somehow never stuck with it. And for some reason I decided I want to give Nyxt a try now.

Here‚Äôs a few things after a few days of using it.

No clutter

Look at how freaking minimal this is! 2 lines at the bottom (and one of them usually empty). THATS. IT.

I‚Äôm not missing anything.

Open anything, very fast

using o in vi mode (or ctrl+l in emacs/cua mode) runs the command set-url, which is just awesome. by default it will either open the URL you type or search for something (when it‚Äôs not an url). But in the prompt it will also show you e.g. the global history, already open buffers or bookmarks. you can jump between the types by using m+n and m+p. ctrl+n and ctrl+p are for navigating single entries. I also like that it ‚Äúpreviews‚Äù the buffer when I hover over an existing one (it also loads currently unloaded ones. Not sure I like that too much, though).

a REAL command prompt

There are omnibars for chrome/firefox. I‚Äôve used some of them in the past. But the integration is always a bit‚Ä¶ meh. Nyxt comes with a command prompt you would expect from a Emacs-inspired browser. It even shows the keybindings (though I still miss which-key):

MOOOODDEEESSS

There are already quite some modes implemented (in lisp) to show you what is possible:

  • no-image-mode -> Don‚Äôt download images
  • no-script-mode -> Don‚Äôt run scripts
  • cruise-control-mode -> automatically scroll down
  • dark-mode (see gif above!)
  • force-https-mode
  • proxy-mode (YES! PER BUFFER! there‚Äôs ways to make it global)
  • repeat-mode
  • and many more!

Extensibility

This is all just ‚Äúbuiltin‚Äù stuff ready to be changed and extended, or ‚Äúmolded‚Äù as some emacsers would say. I know it‚Äôs common lisp‚Ä¶ But IMO still better than a new vimscript üòú

Btw. this whole blog post was written with only the below vi snippet in my configfile, so this is a topic I‚Äôll have to explore‚Ä¶

Warts

The unicorn sadly does have a few warts I noticed.

Vi mode everywhere? NO!

The documentation only shows you how to enable vi mode globally. This is really ugly. If you enable vi mode and then press e.g. o to open a new buffer, you‚Äôre still in vi-normal mode. This means you have to press oi to be able to start typing in the prompt. Like : in vim I expect to be in a more emacs-y mode when opening any prompt.

The proper snippet to fix this is (the :web-buffer is very important here):

(define-configuration :web-buffer
  ((default-modes (append (list :vi-normal-mode) %slot-value%))))

Enter the common lisp community

The editor is mostly written and extensible by using common lisp. This is fine (I guess). But be ready to embrace the common lisp world! I‚Äôm not there yet, which is why I‚Äôm still mostly confused from the best example configuration. I‚Äôm learning about asdf, quicklisp and have to look at stuff like ace which I don‚Äôt really want to know about. (WHY do you want to transform a browser into an editor????).

Thinking about it though, this is no different than emacs/vim. My brain is full of all these emacs-specific things and (n)vim is even worse - the amount of package managers from vim is insane!

I‚Äôm used to a browser that just works ‚Ñ¢Ô∏è and have to shift my mindset a bit.

Enter passtrough mode - forever!

I use silverbullet to take notes (and write this blog) but when I enter the passthrough-mode and type something, I just can‚Äôt exit passthrough mode anymore.

Hidden links

One of the main features of this browser is the keyboard driven experience. This seems still a bit in it‚Äôs infancy though. I really like the idea of being able to search for the text OR be able to type a 2 letter shortcut (much better than qutebrowser, even if you have to type Enter to actually follow!), but when it‚Äôs underneath the prompt, well, bad luck, you will not see what you select.

WTF is this buffer list

I really don‚Äôt get this ugly buffer list from such a ‚Äúminimal‚Äù browser. Why all the margins? Why not make all Divs the same width? This could be an issue of personal taste, though.

What I really don‚Äôt get is that it doesn‚Äôt even update automatically? You really want me to click the ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù button after I‚Äôve deleted a Buffer? Isn‚Äôt the whole joke of this browser that there are all kinds of hooks to automatically do such things for me?

Random Freezes

It happened a few times that when i pressed o to open a new URL, the browser just froze. I had to shoot the process in the head. I have no clue what caused it - it seemed to happen at random times - but I hope that I‚Äôll eventually see a pattern if it happens again. But given that my Firefox config had it‚Äôs own share of freezes (probably using too many extensions üòÑ), I‚Äôm sadly a bit used to this.

Sloppy Search

I‚Äôm used to google search. It‚Äôs fast and VERY accurate. the default search https://search.atlas.engineer is neither. I‚Äôm sorry but the results are just horrible. I searched for a local company with ‚ÄúCOMPANYNAME zurich‚Äù and it only gave me american stuff (and surprisingly many linkedin links). I assume they have this as default search to hopefully gather some insights on who is using nyxt. And I thought I‚Äôll try to get along with it. But I can‚Äôt.

Broken in-document search

Searching in a document is very satisfying. IF it works. E.g. you can‚Äôt really search in a file opened on Github!

Conclusion

I really like Nyxt. The few awesome examples don‚Äôt look like much, but they change the UX completely. There are quite some pain points - but most of them can be fixed with some configuration.

The Pros definitely outweigh the cons!
